content.title: Introduction To Energy Data
content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

Data are vital in influencing evidence-based decision making throughout the energy sector. Identifying the gap between the existing situation and the ideal vision (whether current or future), which is an essential stage in policy making, requires data. For instance, data are necessary for providing information on current conditions, revealing areas for improvement, and offering actionable insights. Without a strong rationale backed up by data, the policy can be implemented incorrectly, negatively impacting people. The role of data in policy making in the energy sector is imperative. This lesson breaks down the key qualities of energy data—like accuracy, reliability, and timeliness—and why they matter for making better decisions. It also looks at how data fits into the policy-making process, from spotting problems and setting goals to tracking progress and checking results. With practical examples and case studies, we’ll see how data can help shape energy policies that work for everyone.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: data quality metrics
concepts.body: Data quality metrics are standards or measures used to assess the accuracy, completeness, consistency, and reliability of data.

concepts.title: data-driven decision making
concepts.body: Data-driven decision making is the process of making choices based on data analysis and interpretation rather than intuition or personal experience.

concepts.title: Energy Data
concepts.body: Energy data refers to the quantitative and qualitative information related to the production, consumption, distribution, and performance of energy systems. This encompasses metrics such as generation capacity, fuel consumption, efficiency, emissions, and cost indicators, all of which are critical for monitoring system performance, informing policy decisions, and optimizing energy operations.

content.text: Data play a crucial role in enhancing governmental transparency and fostering public engagement in energy governance. By enabling central governments (e.g., Ministries of Energy), grid operators, energy distribution companies, and generation companies to share real-time information—such as energy supply, demand, and infrastructure performance—governments can empower a wide range of stakeholders, including NGOs, research institutions, and local communities, to identify overlooked challenges in the energy system and co-create actionable recommendations. This collaborative approach strengthens accountability, bridges gaps between policymakers and frontline actors, and broadens the perspectives included in decision-making. Historical trends in energy production, consumption, trade, and distribution provide a robust foundation for strategic planning. Analyzing these patterns helps decision-makers anticipate future challenges and opportunities while developing models to simulate various scenarios. These simulations can incorporate factors such as technological advances, policy shifts, changes in consumer behavior, and the impact of natural or man-made disasters, offering valuable insights into potential outcomes and supporting evidence-based strategies. Additionally, data are essential for evaluating the impact of energy policies and tracking progress toward key goals. By using data-driven modeling, decision-makers can assess the potential effects of policy options before implementation, reducing risks and improving outcomes. Continuous monitoring and evaluation of energy-related initiatives ensure that policies remain effective over time, allowing for necessary adjustments and keeping progress aligned with long-term objectives.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: The importance of reliable, up-to-date, and accurate data in sustainable energy

content.text: Part 1 Overview

Reliable, accurate, and timely data are essential for crafting evidence-based energy policies that drive sustainable development. Without quality data, policy decisions risk being misinformed, leading to ineffective solutions or unintended consequences. According to the International Recommendations for Energy Statistics (UN, 2018), data must meet five critical dimensions of quality to effectively support sound decision-making, as introduced on the next page..
5 dimensions of data quality:
Relevance

The relevance of statistical information reflects the degree to which the information meets or satisfies the current or emerging needs of users. Relevant data are directly applicable to the questions being asked and the decisions being made.
Accuracy and reliability

The accuracy of data reflects the degree to which the information correctly estimates or describes the phenomena it was designed to measure, i.e., the degree of closeness of estimates to true values, with minimum errors. Reliability is an aspect of accuracy. It concerns whether the statistics consistently measure over time the reality they are designed to represent. For data to be accurate and reliable, it needs to be cross-checked with multiple sources, validating it against trusted benchmarks, through regular data audits.
Timeliness and punctuality

Timeliness of information refers to the length of time between the end of the reference period to which the up-to-date information relates and its availability to users. Punctuality refers to whether data are delivered on the dates promised, advertised, or announced (for example, in an official release calendar). Monitoring data collection cycles, ensuring real-time data access through digital platforms and regularly updating data sets helps to improve timeliness and punctuality.
Coherence and comparability

The coherence of energy statistics reflects the degree to which the data are logically connected and mutually consistent; this is to say the degree to which they can be successfully brought together with other statistical information within a broad analytic framework over time. Comparability is a measurement of the impact of differences in applied statistical concepts, measurement tools and procedures when statistics are compared between geographical areas or over time. Standardizing data collection methodologies, maintaining clear documentation of data sources and processes, and regularly checking for discrepancies are helpful to improve data coherence and comparability.
Accessibility and clarity

Accessibility of information refers to the ease with which users can learn of its existence and locate and import it into their own working environment. Clarity refers to the extent to which easily comprehensible metadata are available in cases where the metadata are necessary to give a full understanding of the statistics Source: International Recommendations for Energy Statistics (UN, 2018)
Ensuring data quality involves systematic evaluation and robust management practices. Three widely recognized approaches include:
Self-Assessments
Internal reviews where organizations benchmark their processes against established frameworks to identify strengths and areas for improvement.
Quality Audits / External Audits

Formal evaluations conducted by independent third parties to verify compliance with specific quality standards (e.g., data integrity, statistical processes). These audits follow structured checklists and rigorous protocols, ensuring alignment with regulatory or sector-specific requirements.
Peer Reviews

Informal assessments by external experts, providing valuable insights into methodologies and processes at a higher level, not to check conformity with requirements item by item from a detailed checklist. They are therefore often less structured than formal external audits.

To further enhance data quality, organizations can adopt standardized frameworks, such as the UN National Quality Assurance Framework (NQAF), which supports rigorous data collection and reporting for SDGs. Investments in national statistical agencies, including sufficient funding and staff training, are also essential to maintain reliable and adaptive data systems.

Integrating quality assurance practices into energy data management strengthens the foundation for policy planning, monitoring, and evaluation. By focusing on key dimensions such as relevance, accuracy, timeliness, coherence, and accessibility, organizations can ensure that energy data effectively supports evidence-based decision-making and facilitates sustainable energy transitions.

Reliable, accurate, and timely data are fundamental to the development of energy policies that effectively address sustainability challenges. High-quality data enable informed decision making by providing the evidence needed to analyze complex systems, evaluate trade-offs, and design targeted interventions. By integrating energy data with environmental, economic, and social dimensions, policymakers can craft strategies that align with both local priorities and broader sustainability objectives. Disaggregated data add further value by exposing inequities that may be obscured in aggregated statistics. For instance, analyzing energy access by gender, geographic area, or income level helps identify specific barriers faced by marginalized groups. This level of granularity ensures that policies are not only technically sound but also socially inclusive, enabling solutions that address systemic inequities while advancing broader development goals.

In linking local contexts with global frameworks, such as SDGs, data serve as a bridge between high-level objectives and actionable strategies. By providing insights into localized conditions and challenges, energy data enable the translation of global targets into practical, context-sensitive measures. This alignment enhances the relevance and impact of energy policies across diverse settings.

Advanced data tools and technologies further expand the possibilities for energy governance. Modeling platforms and scenario analyses rely on precise datasets to simulate potential outcomes, assess risks, and explore the implications of policy choices. These tools not only inform decisions but also provide a means of testing alternative approaches, thereby reducing uncertainties and improving policy outcomes. Transparency and accessibility are equally important in ensuring that data drive meaningful action. Open data systems allow for greater collaboration among stakeholders, while clear and standardized methodologies promote consistency and reliability in analysis. When stakeholders have access to robust and credible data, they are better positioned to coordinate efforts, build trust, and achieve shared objectives.

Investing in the quality and accessibility of energy data is not merely an administrative necessity but a strategic imperative. Accurate, coherent, and actionable data support the development of adaptive policies that address present challenges while anticipating future shifts. By prioritizing inclusivity, relevance, and precision in data strategies, energy systems can better respond to the diverse and evolving needs of communities, ultimately fostering equitable and sustainable transitions.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: The policy cycle and data’s role in decision making

content.text: Part 2 Overview

Energy data play a pivotal role in each stage of the policy cycle, an iterative process designed to plan, monitor, and evaluate policy decisions. The policy cycle, as shown in the following figure, is at the heart of results-based management, ensuring that decisions are informed, adaptable, and inclusive.

In the planning stage, policymakers can use data to understand the situation and set the desired outcomes. Data can help build a complete picture of the issue and identify proximate and ultimate causes, gaps in understanding, and potential areas that could be improved. Also, data can provide evidence of successful outcomes implemented elsewhere, so policymakers have a benchmark against which they can measure their own success or challenges. Data can support modeling complex interactions and systems and allow for analysis of scenarios that simulate different policy strategies by quantifying costs, risks, and benefits. Such analyses can minimize costs, maximize benefits, and optimize effectiveness of interventions.

During the monitoring stage, data are essential for tracking progress, analyzing trends, and evaluating how well ongoing efforts align with predefined objectives. They also help identify temporal factors that influence policy outcomes, whether as facilitators or obstacles. Moreover, making data transparent and accessible fosters public engagement, enabling stakeholders to provide valuable feedback and hold governments accountable for policy implementation.

In the evaluation stage, data are essential for assessing the effectiveness of policies and deriving lessons for future improvements. By identifying which measures succeed and where adjustments are needed, governments can ensure continuous learning and adaptation within the energy sector.

The integration of data into every stage of the policy cycle underscores its transformative potential. To illustrate how data can inform complex decision-making processes, the following case study examines Chile’s efforts to achieve carbon neutrality by leveraging advanced methodologies for financial and investment planning in the energy sector.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | Case Study
content.title: Case Study: Evaluation of Costs and Financial Requirements for Carbon Neutrality in the Chilean Energy Sector

content.text: Climate change is severely affecting Chile, which has suffered from prolonged drought for the past 14 years approximately. Surviving vegetation is under water stress and can burn easily, one of the most visible consequences being the large and tragic fires of 2014, 2017, 2023, and 2024[1]. Chile is committed to fighting against climate change, so it set in 2022 the goal for the country to be carbon neutral and resilient to the effects of climate change by 2050 (Climate Change Framework Law 21.455). To meet this goal, the focus on the energy sector is necessary as it is estimated to be responsible for 78% of the country's GHG emissions. Carbon neutrality is expected to be achieved by establishing mitigation measures in the energy sector and reinforcing the conservation of CO2 capture capacity by the forestry sector [2].

To better assess the costs and the investments needed in the long-term energy planning to reach carbon neutrality by 2050, the Ministry of Energy, in collaboration with the UNDP and the Ministry of Finance, applied between 2020 and 2022 the UNDP’s Investment and Financial Flow Assessment (IFF) Methodology. This methodology aims to inform decision-makers of the capital flow changes needed to accomplish their goal by identifying the measures that will require the most effort, the years in which the most significant contributions should be made, and who should provide the capital for implementing these measures [3].

The data collected to conduct the IFF in Chile is from the Long-Term Energy Planning evaluation for 2023-2027[4]. The analysis was based on the "Moderate Pathway to Carbon Neutrality" scenario proposed on this evaluation. The primary focus was on the mitigation measures to reduce emissions in the energy sector to a level where total GHG emissions are equal or lower than the CO2 capture capacity of the national forests. This encompasses proposed measures for the forestry sector and land-use changes by 2050. The IFF study analyzed 45 GHG mitigation measures across six sectors: transport, housing, public, commercial, mining-industry and electricity. Households and businesses are the ones that will need to change their investment flows the most. The government will need to invest directly in initiatives such as constructing bike lanes, retrofitting housing, and implementing energy efficiency programs, or to subsidize energy shifting programs to install solar energy systems such as “Solar House”. Operation and maintenance (O&M) costs are expected to decrease, resulting in savings. Households will benefit the most from these savings thanks to the reforms in the transport and housing sectors. Business will also benefit from the decrease in O&M but need to invest more first. Overall, the mitigation measures will improve the Chilean quality of life and health and could save up to $267,249 million from 2021 to 2050, mainly benefiting the transportation and residential sectors while supporting energy projects.

Chile is making progress in implementing its NDCs, shifting capital flows towards low-emission energy efficiency and sustainable development measures. Transportation, residential, and public sector initiatives receive most of the state funding, aiming to reduce costs and encourage similar practices. However, financing is not the only barrier to reach carbon neutrality by 2050; social and user perception of environmental benefits are also hindrances. The IFF methodology has proven key in identifying capital flows and responsible entities, aiding in anticipating peak capital requirements. Chile’s case highlights the importance of aligning financial, social, and environmental dimensions in energy policy. It also underscores the need for comprehensive planning that includes sectors like forestry, which are vital for CO2 capture but vulnerable to climate impacts. By prioritizing robust data collection and analysis, Chile exemplifies how governments can develop actionable strategies to achieve ambitious sustainability goals.
References

[1] BBC Mundo (2024) Por qué los incendios en Chile que dejan más de 100 muertos fueron tan destructivos [2] UNDP (2023) Evaluación de costos y requerimientos financieros de la carbono neutralidad en el sector energético chileno [3] UNDP (2009) Guidebook for the Assessment of Investment and Financial Flows to Address Climate Change [4] Ministerio de Energía (2021) Planificación Energética de Largo Plazo (PELP) Periodo 2023-2027 [5] UNDP (2023): Informe IFF Chile

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Data and its Beneficiaries in the Energy Sector

content.text: Part 3 Overview

Data play a transformative role in shaping decisions across the energy sector, enabling diverse stakeholders to achieve their specific objectives while advancing collective goals like energy security, sustainability, and equity. From global organizations to grassroots communities, the spectrum of beneficiaries underscores the wide-ranging applications of energy data in addressing both macro and micro-level challenges.

At the global level, policymakers and international organizations, such as the International Energy Agency, the United Nations, the World Bank, international non-governmental organizations (NGOs), or international or national energy companies rely on comprehensive data sets to formulate energy policies, set targets, and monitor progress toward global energy goals such as emissions reduction and renewable energy deployment. Analysts and researchers utilize data for modelling and forecasting energy trends, conducting impact assessments, and identifying emerging challenges and opportunities in the global energy landscape. Traders, business leaders and financial institutions leverage data for market analysis, risk management, and investment decision-making in energy markets. At the regional and national levels, policymakers, government agencies, and regulatory bodies use data to develop energy policies and regulations tailored to regional or national energy needs, promote energy security, and stimulate economic growth. Local governments and community organizations use data to plan and implement energy efficiency programs, renewable energy projects, and sustainable energy initiatives at the grassroots level. Business leaders in the energy sector rely on data for strategic planning, resource allocation, and operational decision-making to optimize energy production, (international) transport, distribution, and consumption.

Individuals, including middle to large-size energy consumers such as heavy industries (e.g., iron and steel, cement production) and households, benefit from access to energy data for making informed choices about their energy consumption, adopting energy-efficient technologies, and participating in demand-side management programs. Additionally, community-level stakeholders such as nonprofit organizations, advocacy groups, and grassroots movements use data to raise awareness about energy-related issues, mobilize support for policy reforms, and advocate for equitable access to energy services. The beneficiaries' specific interests are closely correlated with the types of data sets they require for informed decision-making and strategic planning. Their interests differ in energy data use; for example, the United Nations will use data on energy consumption and production for some countries to track their development progress. While multinational energy companies will look at the same data to find opportunities to expand their business.
While energy data can be applied in diverse ways, certain types are most frequently utilized across sectors. These datasets generally fall into five core categories:

These categories often intersect with sector-specific (e.g., transport, buildings, industry) or technology-focused data needs, further broadening their relevance and utility. To maximize the impact of energy data, it is vital to ensure its integrity, accessibility, and usability. This requires adherence to principles that prioritize transparency, professionalism, and ethical stewardship. The United Nations’ Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics offer a foundational framework for this, emphasizing the role of credible data in democratic governance, equitable decision-making, and public accountability.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | BOX
content.title: BOX. The fundamental principles of data

content.text: In recognition of the importance, power, and credibility of high-quality data in the policy-making process, the United Nations adopted ten Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics in 2014.

Principle 1. Official statistics provide an indispensable element in the information system of a democratic society, serving the Government, the economy and the public with data about the economic, demographic, social and environmental situation. To this end, official statistics that meet the test of practical utility are to be compiled and made available on an impartial basis by official statistical agencies to honor citizens’ entitlement to public information. Principle 2. To retain trust in official statistics, the statistical agencies need to decide according to strictly professional considerations, including scientific principles and professional ethics, on the methods and procedures for the collection, processing, storage and presentation of statistical data.

Principle 3. To facilitate a correct interpretation of the data, the statistical agencies are to present information according to scientific standards on the sources, methods and procedures of the statistics. Principle 4. The statistical agencies are entitled to comment on erroneous interpretation and misuse of statistics. Principle 5. Data for statistical purposes may be drawn from all types of sources, be they statistical surveys or administrative records. Statistical agencies are to choose the source with regard to quality, timeliness, costs and the burden on respondents. Principle 6. Individual data collected by statistical agencies for statistical compilation, whether they refer to natural or legal persons, are to be strictly confidential and used exclusively for statistical purposes.

Principle 7. The laws, regulations and measures under which the statistical systems operate are to be made public. Principle 8. Coordination among statistical agencies within countries is essential to achieve consistency and efficiency in the statistical system. Principle 9. The use by statistical agencies in each country of international concepts, classifications and methods promotes the consistency and efficiency of statistical systems at all official levels. Principle 10. Bilateral and multilateral cooperation in statistics contributes to the improvement of systems of official statistics in all countries.

content.title: Learning Objectives
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Reliable, accurate, and timely data are essential for sustainable energy policies.
takeaways.description: High-quality data ensures that energy policies are evidence-based, minimizing risks of misinformed decisions and unintended consequences. By meeting critical dimensions of data quality—relevance, accuracy, timeliness, coherence, and accessibility—policymakers can design effective strategies that drive sustainable development and address complex energy challenges.

takeaways.title: Data is integral to every stage of the policy cycle, from planning to evaluation.
takeaways.description: In the planning stage, data helps identify gaps and set goals; during monitoring, it tracks progress and aligns efforts with objectives; and in evaluation, it assesses policy effectiveness and informs future improvements. This iterative, data-driven approach ensures that energy policies remain adaptive, inclusive, and aligned with long-term sustainability goals.

takeaways.title: Energy data benefits a wide range of stakeholders, from global organizations to local communities.
takeaways.description: Policymakers, businesses, researchers, and individuals all rely on energy data to achieve their objectives, whether it’s setting global energy targets, optimizing investments, or making informed consumption choices. Disaggregated data also helps address equity issues, ensuring that energy policies are inclusive and responsive to the needs of marginalized groups.
